Hello, I'm Amanda.

Hello! My name is Amanda Billy, and I live, work, and play on the Internet. I’m good at helping people use the web to connect. In the last eight years, I’ve put my skills to good use at two startups, two universities, and a church (usually with some overlap).

I live in Jacksonville, Florida, where the summers are too hot and the air is too wet, but the water views and the avenues of oak trees are beautiful enough to make up for it. In my spare time, I like to photograph my dogs, binge watch television shows, and cook new recipes.

I'm a bit of a generalistgeneralist, multitasker, wild card.

Work Experience

Adjunct Instructor University of Florida

October 2013 - Present

I teach graduate students how to design and build responsive, interactive web sites using fluid widths, media queries, and progressive enhancement. The class includes lessons on semantic coding, mobile first web design and development, device-agnostic accessibility and usability, design prototyping, and jQuery.

Skills: Teaching, curriculum development, assessment development, feedback and criticism

Work: Example document, JSFiddle

Secretary First Christian Church

January 2006 - July 2010, July 2012 - Present

My primary job function is to create and distribute communications to church members, partners, and staff. I also designed, built, and maintain the church web site; manage a building management system I created to eliminate double booking problems; coordinate church lay leaders as they perform their duties; and maintain a series of Google calendars to facilitate staff organization and communication. In 2014, I also created and co-managed the Untalent Show, a new spring fundraiser for the church's operating fund. The event garnered rave reviews from church members and raised more than $1200, a huge success for a fundraiser's first time out.

  • firstchristianjax.com
  • Untalent Show Program

Design Intern CoWork Jax

January 2013 - April 2013

I designed and developed print and web materials for this fast-paced startup, and designed and built a custom responsive WordPress theme for a corporate offshoot. I also contributed to the staff blog, which used the WordPress CMS, every week.

  • jaxfastpitch.com (not maintained and therefore not fully functional)
  • CoWork Jax Tumblr
  • CoWork Jax Rack Cards
  • CoWork Jax Blog Contributions

Editorial Assistant Xomba

January 2010 - April 2010, July 2010 - September 2011

At this five-man web startup, I acted as the company generalist. I was responsible for community management, blogging, customer service (including disgruntled-member wrangling), technical support, site moderation, copy writing, social media, web analytics, Wiki management, and QA testing.

  • Previous
  • Next

Student Assistant Univ. of N. Florida LGBT Resource Center

September 2009 - April 2010

My key achievement in my time at the LGBTRC was the establishment of an online presence for the Center. I created a WordPress blog (now obsolete, unfortunately) and a Facebook Page and trained the Center faculty and staff to use them. I also participated in the Speakers' Bureau panel discussions in a variety of settings and organized the most widely attended and financially successful fundraising drag show the university had seen in three years.

Volunteer Work

Christmount Post-College Retreat

Co-founder, co-organizer. I'm no longer sure whose idea the Christmount Post-College Retreat was, but Katie Rose, Jamie Brame, and I ultimately created it. One of my most substantial material contributions: the CPCR website, hosted on WordPress.com. I can't take credit for the design or development of the theme, but I created the header images from stock photography, and I wrote all of the body copy.

Skills: Copy writing, Adobe Photoshop CS5

  • Christmount Post-College Retreat

Education

Masters: Web Design and Online Communications University of Florida

January 2012 - December 2013

Bachelors: Journalism University of North Florida

August 2005 - April 2010

Arts Seal: Creative Writing Douglas Anderson School of the Arts

August 2001 - May 2005

I know, I know. Who includes high school on their resume? I do, and I include it because it was four years of intensive training in creative writing. I attended an arts school, the sort of place you have to audition to get into (yes, like Fame), and, every year, I had to balance a certain number of classes in my major with all the state-mandated academic ones. I was also required to participate in at least one performance each year. My high school experience involved learning layout and design, event planning, volunteer management, public speaking, and event marketing. I think that's worth bragging about.
